subNodes.conversationText: root

Stone demons with menacing smiles -- funerary statues, evidently -- flanked a casket in this part of the cavern. The casket was wooden, simple, and unadorned, except for a runner of red silk draped over the lid. A poem was carved into the cave wall.
The young witch read the poem.

Honeysuckle fades
The scent of plum in winter
Sweet against harsh white.
The young witch opened the casket.
The young witch left the tomb alone.
The young witch examined the statues.
The young witch opened the casket.
A skeleton lay inside. It wore ancient armor and slept beside a sword. A paper ribbon with the words "No lord but time" in calligraphy was wrapped around the mouth.
[Continue.]
A hollow voice came from the body in the casket, but it did not move. "Wanderer, the sword is restless that drank its fill centuries ago, that clung to me like my own mortality. Take it."
<He/She> did.
The stone demons sprang to life.
[End.]
[Skip combat.]

actions.a_parameter_1: The young witch doesn't have the skill to wield this sword as a weapon, but <he/she> can carry it in her left hand to take advantage of its protective magics.

subNodes.conversationText: <He/She> did.
The stone demons sprang to life.
<FirstName> didn't trust the voice. <He/She> left the sword alone.

The skeleton was laid out just like the last one the young witch had discovered, but the sword had a different look. Otherwise, everything was the same, down to the ribbon saying "No lord but time" where the skeleton's lips would have been.
And so the young witch discovered a third skeleton entombed as the other two had been, though the sword, once again, was different.
As the young witch expected, this skeleton had the same accoutrements as the other three, including a unique sword.
The young witch examined the statues.

Their style was archaic, their expression imposing. The witch sensed the unsettling presence of discordium, so antithetical to <his/her> kind of magic. It made the already forbidding cell even more sinister.
The young witch read the poem.
The young witch opened the casket.
The young witch left the tomb alone.
The young witch left the tomb alone.
The young witch returned to the casket.
<He/She> read the poem on the wall.

Honeysuckle fades
The scent of plum in winter
Sweet against harsh white.
<He/She> examined the statues.

Their style was archaic, their expression imposing. The witch sensed the unsettling presence of discordium, so antithetical to <his/her> kind of magic. It made the already forbidding cell even more sinister.
<He/She> opened the casket.
A skeleton lay inside. It wore ancient armor and slept beside a sword. A paper ribbon with the words "No lord but time" in calligraphy was wrapped around the mouth.
<He/She> took the sword.
The stone demons sprang to life.

<FirstName> found <him/her>self in another cave with a casket. The furnishings were identical to those <he/she>'d seen before, but the poem was different.
<He/She> read it.

Honeysuckle fades
The scent of plum in winter
Sweet against harsh white.
The young witch opened the casket.
It was as before: four stone demons, a casket, a poem.
<He/She> read the poem.

Sweet against harsh white.
The young witch had stumbled upon a fourth tomb.
